questions.text: A 42-year-old man presented with a history of heartburn after heavy meals for the past 4 years. A biopsy of the lower esophageal mucosa is obtained by upper gastrointestinal endoscopy. The microscopic picture is shown below. What is the most likely cellular adaptation observed?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the image showing the replacement of stratified squamous epithelium with intestinal-type columnar epithelium with goblet cells is suggestive of Barret's esophagus. The most likely cellular adaptation observed is metaplasia. 

Metaplasia is a reversible cellular adaptation characterized by the replacement of one differentiated cell type (epithelial or mesenchymal) by another cell type. It usually represents an adaptive response in which one cell type is replaced by another more capable of handling the stressor. 

The various types of metaplasia are:

  • Squamous metaplasia - 
    • Airways - normal pseudostratified epithelium is replaced by the squamous epithelium. It may occur due to chronic smoking or a deficiency of retinoic acid
    • Urinary bladder - normal transitional epithelium is replaced by squamous epithelium. It may occur due to bladder stones 
  • Columnar metaplasia - 
    • Esophagus - normal squamous epithelium of the esophagus is replaced by the glandular columnar epithelium (Barret's esophagus). It may occur in patients with chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease
  • Connective tissue metaplasia - 
    • Muscle - formation of bone in the muscle tissue; the condition is known as myositis ossificans. This may occur secondary to intramuscular hemorrhage

The images below show squamous and columnar metaplasia, respectively. 

Other options:

Option B: Hyperplasia is a cellular adaptation characterized by an increase in the number of cells, thereby, resulting in an increase in organ size. Such an example is the glandular hyperplasia of the female breast during puberty and pregnancy.

Option C: Atrophy is a decrease in the size of the tissue or organ due to the reduction in the cell number and size. Such an example is muscle atrophy after nerve injury.

Option D: Dysplasia is a cellular adaptation characterized by disordered cellular architecture (increased mitoses, increased nucleus: cytoplasm ratio) and growth that predisposes to malignancy.

questions.text: A child was brought to the pediatric emergency with complaints of him appearing lethargic and irritable when touched. On examination, his skin is dry, eyes are sunken and hyperreflexia is present. Blood reports show serum sodium to be 150 mEq/L and high serum osmolarity. Which of the following is correct regarding the initial resuscitation of this case?
questions.solution:
The given scenario describing a lethargic child with hyperreflexia, irritability, dry skin, and sunken eyes in the setting of hypernatremia is suggestive of hypernatremic dehydration. The initial resuscitation should include a slow infusion of normal saline rather than ringer lactate.

Hypernatremic dehydration is the most dangerous type of dehydration. Children are often lethargic, and they may be irritable when touched. Hypernatremia may cause fever, hypertonicity, and hyperreflexia. 

Hypernatremia causes the movement of water from brain cells into the hypertonic extracellular fluid, causing brain cell shrinkage and shearing of blood vessels within the brain. If not treated can lead to central nervous system hemorrhages and thrombosis.

The fluid deficit is corrected slowly as rapid treatment of hypernatremic dehydration causes the movement of water from the extracellular space into brain cells, leading to cerebral edema, seizures, brain herniation, and even death. To minimize the risk of cerebral edema during the correction of hypernatremic dehydration, the serum sodium concentration should not decrease by >10 mEq/L every 24 hr. The deficits in severe hypernatremic dehydration may need to be corrected over 2-4 days.

The initial resuscitation requires the restoration of intravascular volume with normal saline (NS). Ringers lactate should not be used as it is more hypotonic than NS and may result in a very rapid decrease in serum concentrations, especially if multiple fluid boluses are necessary.

(Note: Vice versa for hyponatremic dehydration, if hyponatremic dehydration is treated rapidly with 3% saline, it increases the risk of central pontine myelinolysis)

questions.text: An unconscious young man was rushed to the emergency department. On examination, his pulse rate was 190/min and his blood pressure was 70/40 mmHg. His electrocardiogram is given below. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the electrocardiogram (ECG) showing narrow QRS complexes without P waves and pseudo R waves in aVR lead suggest paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). As the patient is hemodynamically unstable, the next step in management is DC (direct current) cardioversion.

PSVT is a narrow QRS complex tachycardia with sudden onset and termination. They mainly present with dizziness and palpitations. Evaluation of these patients includes monitoring of vitals and ECG.

Management is as follows:

1) When the patient is hemodynamically stable:

  • Carotid sinus massage can be done. It is avoided if carotid bruit is present and if a prior history of stroke is seen
  • Valsalva maneuver is done if the patient is cooperative
  • Intravenous adenosine is useful in most cases. However, its usage is contraindicated in patients with prior cardiac transplantation. It can aggravate bronchospasm and atrial fibrillation, hence must be used with great caution in such patients.
  • Intravenous calcium channel blockers such as verapamil or diltiazem and beta-blockers are helpful but can cause hypotension.

2) When the patient is hemodynamically unstable, i.e. when the patient has hypotension with unconsciousness or respiratory distress QRS-synchronous direct current cardioversion is done.

questions.text: A female patient presented with midline neck swelling to the outpatient department. While examining the thyroid gland, you observe that the swelling does not extend superiorly. which of the following structure is responsible for that?
questions.solution:
The upward extension of the thyroid swelling is prevented by the attachment of the sternothyroid to the thyroid cartilage. The thyroid gland can only enlarge anteriorly, posteriorly, laterally, and inferiorly. The superior extension of thyroid swelling is limited by two muscles namely: sternothyroid and sternohyoid.

Other options:

Option A: Thyrohyoid membrane is a fibro-elastic ligament, which arises from the superior margin of the thyroid cartilage, and gets attached to the hyoid bone. It facilitates the upward movement of the larynx during swallowing.

Option C: Pretrachial fascia encloses the thyroid gland and is attached to the larynx. This attachment is responsible for the movement of the enlarged thyroid gland on deglutition.

Option D: The ligament of berry, also called suspensory ligament extends from the cricoid cartilage to the thyroid. Its attachment prevents the thyroid gland from sinking down into the mediastinum.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with fever, loose stools, and blood in the stool. On microscopic examination, plenty of pus cells were found and culture on MacConkey agar showed colorless colonies. What is the enrichment medium used to isolate the organism from the stool sample?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of dysentery (bloody stools) and abdominal pain in a child is suggestive of bacillary dysentery most likely caused due to Shigella. Selenite F broth is used as an enrichment media for dysentery-causing bacteria like Shigella.

Enrichment media is used to suppress commensal bacteria while allowing the pathogen to remain viable and grow.

Shigellae are short, gram-negative rods that are non-motile, non-sporing, and non-capsulated. They are indole positive, urea and oxidase negative, and ferment glucose. Colonies on MacConkey agar are colorless due to the absence of lactose fermentation. Hektoen enteric (HE) agar, xylose-lysine-deoxycholate agar (XLD), and deoxycholate citrate agar (DCA) are the highly selective mediums used for subculture. Growth is inhibited on Wilson and Blair bismuth sulphite medium.

Dysentery/Shigellosis is a type of food poisoning caused by infection with the Shigella species. It acts by inactivating the 60s ribosomal subunit thereby inhibiting protein synthesis. It is spread through faeco-oral transmission. It causes acute onset of symptoms (fever, abdominal cramps) with dysentery and tenesmus. It also gives a positive Sereny test.

Other options:

Option A: Robertson's cooked meat broth is used for the culture of anaerobic organisms. 

Option B: Alkaline peptone water is used for vibrio cholera causing watery diarrhea. It is an enrichment media.

Option D: Brain-heart infusion broth is an enriched media. It is used for the cultivation of fastidious organisms.

questions.text: A young patient who is a known case of glaucoma presented with sudden onset of decreased vision. Following an ophthalmic examination, a provisional diagnosis of glaukomflecken was made. This condition refers to:

choices.text: Posterior subcapsular opacities secondary to angle closure glaucoma
Anterior subcapsular opacities secondary to angle closure glaucoma
Corneal opacity secondary to open angle glaucoma
Corneal opacity secondary to angle closure glaucoma

questions.solution:
Glaukomflecken refers to anterior subcapsular lenticular opacity secondary to angle-closure glaucoma.

Marked elevation of intraocular pressure in acute congestive angle closure may cause small anterior grey-white subcapsular or capsular opacities to form within the pupillary area. This is called glaukomflecken and indicates focal infarcts of the lens epithelium. This finding is strongly suggestive of a previous episode of acute congestive angle closure.

The images below show glaukomflecken in a patient with angle closure glaucoma. 

Vogt's triad is seen after an acute attack of primary angle closure. It includes glaukomflecken, patches of iris atrophy, and a slightly dilated nonreactive pupil.

In angle-closure glaucoma, there is an apposition of the peripheral iris against the trabecular meshwork. Furthermore, there is obstruction of aqueous outflow by the closure of an already narrow angle of the anterior chamber resulting in an increase in intraocular pressure.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis and was started on first-line antitubercular drugs. Which of the following drugs acts by inhibiting the production of mycolic acid?
questions.solution:
Isoniazid is the first-line antitubercular drug that acts by inhibiting the synthesis of mycolic acid.

Isoniazid is a first-line bactericidal drug that is used for the treatment of tuberculosis. This drug enters bacilli by passive diffusion. It then gets activated to its toxic form by the enzyme catalase-peroxidase (the enzyme encoded by the Kat gene).

Normally, InhA and KasA are involved in the synthesis of mycolic acid. Upon activation, the reactive metabolite of isoniazid forms complexes with NAD that inhibit InhA and KasA. Hence, isoniazid inhibits the production of mycolic acid.

The reactive isoniazid metabolite also forms complexes with NADP. This complex inhibits mycobacterial dihydrofolate reductase which results in the interruption of DNA synthesis.

Side effects of isoniazid include:

  • Peripheral neuritis due to interference with the production of active coenzyme pyridoxal phosphate from pyridoxine. Therefore, pyridoxine 10 mg/day (vitamin B6) is given prophylactically along with isoniazid to prevent neurotoxicity.
  • Hepatitis- isoniazid must be stopped at the first sign of hepatotoxicity.
  • Rashes
  • Anemia
  • Arthralgia

Toxicity of isoniazid results in metabolic acidosis and seizures. 

Other options:

Option B: Rifampin is the first-line antitubercular drug. It binds to DNA-dependent RNA polymerase to form a stable drug-enzyme complex. This complex suppresses RNA synthesis. Side effects of rifampin are hepatitis, flu-like illness, and urine and secretions may become orange-red but this is harmless.

Option C: Pyrazinamide is a prodrug that is activated by the enzyme pyrazinamidase (encoded by the pncA gene). It is converted into an active metabolite pyrazinoic acid. This metabolite makes the intracellular environment acidic which collapses the transmembrane proton motive force, thereby killing the bacteria. Hepatotoxicity and hyperuricemia are the common side effects.

Option D: Ethambutol inhibits arabinose transferase III, thereby decreasing arabinogalactan biosynthesis. This results in disruption in mycobacterial cell wall synthesis. The important side effect of ethambutol is optic neuritis, resulting in decreased visual acuity and loss of red-green discrimination.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male patient presents with fever, headache, cough with scanty sputum, and a sore throat for the past 2 weeks. He also complains of multiple joint pains. A chest x-ray is shown below. Culture shows a fried egg appearance on PPLO agar. Which of the following treatment options would not be recommended for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with symptoms of a URTI, arthralgias, and culture showing fried egg appearance on PPLO agar is suggestive of atypical pneumonia caused by mycoplasma. It does not warrant the use of ciprofloxacin as treatment.

Mycoplasma is a major cause of atypical pneumonia in both children and adults. Clinically it has a very non-specific presentation and commonly presents with URTI (tracheobronchitis/ pharyngitis), wheezing, and cough. It is also characterized by its extrapulmonary manifestations. Extrapulmonary manifestations include cold agglutinin disease (IgM mediated AIHA), Erythema multiforme or SJS, arthralgia with adenopathy, Guillain-Barre syndrome, myocarditis, pericarditis, and encephalitis.

Investigations include PCR of respiratory secretions and chest x-rays. On chest x-ray, the most common pattern is that of peribronchial pneumonia with thickened bronchial markings, streaky interstitial infiltrations, and sub-segmental atelectasis. On PPLO agar (Dienes method) it shows a biphasic with fried-egg appearance.

Treatment options for Mycoplasma pneumoniae infection include:

  • Macrolides (e.g. azithromycin)
  • Tetracyclines (e.g. doxycycline)
  • Respiratory fluoroquinolones (e.g. levofloxacin)

Azithromycin is the drug of choice for management. Doxycycline is the second-best drug for the management of atypical pneumonia.

However, ciprofloxacin and ofloxacin are not recommended because of their high minimal inhibitory concentrations against Mycoplasma pneumoniae isolates and their poor performance in experimental studies.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to the outpatient department with reduced hearing for the past 2-3 months. He was diagnosed with serous otitis media. What is the otoscopy finding you expect in this child?

choices.text: Hemorrhagic blebs on the tympanic membrane
A dull and opaque tympanic membrane with clear effusion
A pearly white mass in the deep meatus

questions.solution:
Otoscopy of serous otitis media shows a dull and opaque tympanic membrane with clear effusion.

Serous otitis media is also known as secretory otitis media or mucoid otitis media or glue ear. It is characterized by the accumulation of nonpurulent effusion in the middle ear cleft. 

The causes of serous otitis media include malfunctioning of the eustachian tube (adenoid hyperplasia, chronic sinusitis or tonsillitis or rhinitis, palatal defects, tumors of nasopharynx) or increased secretory activity of the middle ear mucosa (allergy, unresolved otitis media, viral infections).

It is often seen in children 5-8 years of age. They present with hearing loss, delayed and defective speech, and mild earaches with upper respiratory tract infections.

Otoscopy reveals a dull, opaque, and retracted tympanic membrane with loss of light reflex, a thin leash of vessels along the handle of the malleus, fluid levels, and air bubbles behind the tympanic membrane.

 

The tuning fork test reveals a conductive type of hearing loss and audiometry reveals hearing loss in the range of 20-40 dB. Impedance audiometry shows reduced compliance and a flat curve shifted to the negative side due to the presence of fluid.

Treatment includes medical management with decongestants, antihistamines, antibiotics, and middle ear aeration. Surgical management includes myringotomy and aspiration of fluid, grommet insertion, tympanotomy, or cortical mastoidectomy.

Other options: 

Option A: Myringitis bullosa is characterized by painful hemorrhagic blebs on the tympanic membrane. It is associated with infection by Mycoplasma or a virus.

Option C: Acute otitis media is an acute infection of the middle ear by pyogenic organisms. It presents with throbbing earache, tinnitus, hearing loss, and cart-wheel appearance of the tympanic membrane on examination.

The image given below shows the cart-wheel appearance of the tympanic membrane seen in acute otitis media.

Option D: A pearly white mass in the deep meatus is seen in keratosis obturans.

Indications:
  • Acute suppurative otitis media:
    • Severe earache with the bulging tympanic membrane.
    • Incomplete resolution with opaque drum and persistent conductive deafness.
    • Complications of acute otitis media,e.g.facialparalysis, labyrinthitis or meningitis with the bulging tympanic membrane.
  • Serous otitis media.
  • Aero-otitis media (to drain fluid and “unlock” the eustachian tube).
  • Atelectatic ear (grommet is often inserted for long-term aeration).

Contraindication: Suspected intratympanic glomus tumor.

Incisions: 

  • In acute suppurative otitis media, a circumferential incision is made in the posteroinferior quadrant of the tympanic membrane, midway between the handle of malleus and tympanic annulus, avoiding injury to the incudostapedial joint.
  • In serous otitis media, a small radial incision is given in the anteroinferior quadrant and all the effusion is sucked out.

Complications:

  • Injury to incudostapedial joint or stapes.
  • Injury to jugular bulb with profuse bleeding, if jugular bulb is high and floor of the middle ear dehiscent.
  • Middle ear infection.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male patient presented with pain in the right knee region for the past three months. On examination, the right knee region is swollen and there is a reduced range of motion. An x-ray taken for further evaluation reveals the following. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the x-ray showing an expansile, eccentric, sub-articular soap bubble appearance is suggestive of Giant cell tumor (GCT) or Osteoclastoma.

Osteoclastoma usually affects young adults of age 20 to 40 years with slight female predominance. It is seen exclusively in adults and affects the epiphysis of long bones, commonly in the distal end of the femur followed by the proximal tibia. Common presenting complaints are swelling and vague pain. Sometimes, the patient presents for the first time with a pathological fracture through the lesion.

  • Important x-ray features of a GCT
    • A solitary, possibly loculated, lytic lesion in the epiphysis.
    • Eccentric location, most often subchondral.
    • Expansion of the overlying cortex.
    • Soap bubble appearance - The tumor is homogeneously lytic with trabeculae of the remnants of bone traversing it, giving it a loculated appearance called soap bubble appearance.
    • No calcification within the tumor.
    • No or minimal reactive sclerosis around the tumor.

Histologically, GCTs consist of undifferentiated spindle cells profusely interspersed with multi-nucleated giant cells. The tumor stroma is well-vascularized with bands of cellular or collagenous fibrous tissue. The image below shows the histopathology of osteoclastoma.

The treatment of choice for GCT is extended curettage and bone grafting.

  • GCT in the relatively insignificant bone like distal ulna, clavicle, and proximal fibula is treated by resection without reconstruction.
  • Bisphosphonates have been shown to reduce the proliferation of osteoclasts and hence have been shown to stabilize local and metastatic disease.
  • Radiation can be used for spinal or sacral tumors.

Other options:

Option A: Aneurysmal bone cyst is a benign, expansile lytic lesion of the metaphysis of the long bones, comprised of blood-filled cystic spaces. It is more common in the age group of 5-20 years. These occur more commonly in the metaphysis of the long bones like the femur, tibia, and humerus. Patients usually present with pain and swelling. The x-ray image is given below:

 

Option B: Osteochondromas are benign bone tumors that present commonly in the adolescent age group. Radiograph and MRI would reveal pedunculated bony protuberance with a stalk with a growing cartilaginous cap (as shown below) or some lesions with a broad sessile base.

 

Option D: Osteosarcoma occurs most commonly in the second decade of life. It is typically metaphyseal. The distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus are the common sites. The periosteal reaction is the typical finding and it may take the form of a Codman's triangle or it may have a sunburst (sunray) appearance (as shown below) on the X-ray.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the psychiatry OPD with complaints of low mood for the past 2 weeks, reduced socialization, decreased appetite, and inability to sleep for the past 3 months. She also complains of frequent backache and headache, with early morning awakening. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of low mood for the past 2 weeks along with reduced appetite, reduced interest in socialization, somatic symptoms, and disturbed sleep, points towards a diagnosis of depression (major depressive disorder). 

The diagnostic criteria for major depressive disorder are:

A. Five or more of the following symptoms have been present during the same 2-week period. Atleast one of the symptoms is either depressed mood or loss of interest or pleasure.

  1. Depressed mood most of the day
  2. Markedly diminished interest or pleasure in activities (anhedonia)
  3. Significant weight loss when not dieting or weight gain, decrease or increase in appetite
  4. Insomnia or hypersomnia
  5. Psychomotor agitation or retardation
  6. Fatigue or loss of energy
  7. Feelings of worthlessness or excessive or inappropriate guilt
  8. Diminished ability to think or concentrate, or indecisiveness
  9. Recurrent thoughts of death, recurrent suicidal ideation

B. The symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupa­tional, or other important areas of functioning.

C. The episode is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or to another medical condition.

D. The occurrence of the major depressive episode is not better explained by schizoaf­fective disorder, schizophrenia, schizophreniform disorder, delusional disorder, or other specified and unspecified schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorders.

E. There has never been a manic episode or a hypomanic episode.

Other Options:

Option A: Conversion disorder is a condition with symptoms or deficits that involve voluntary motor or sensory functions. Though it points to an underlying medical condition, in reality, it arises due to psychological factors. The symptoms are not intentionally produced and the gain obtained is primarily psychological. 

It can be associated with depressive disorders, anxiety disorders, personality disorders, and somatization disorders. Paralysis, blindness, and mutism are the most frequently seen conversion disorder symptoms. Anesthesia and paresthesia of the extremities, abnormal movements, and gait disturbance are the other features commonly seen. 

Option B: Somatic symptom disorder is characterized by the fear of having a serious illness based on the person's misinterpretation of bodily symptoms. The symptoms are persistent for over 6 months. It equally affects men and women and is commonly seen in the third decade of life. It is associated with poor insight. Patients believe that they have a serious disease that has not yet been detected and they can­not be persuaded otherwise. Their convictions persist despite negative laboratory results, the benign course of the alleged disease over time, and reassurances from doctors.

Option C:  Dysthymic disorder is the presence of a persistently depressed mood that lasts most of the day and is continuous. There are also feelings of guilt, irritability, and anger associated with it. These symptoms are present for at least 2 years. It is distinguished from major depressive disorder by the fact that patients mention that they have always been depressed. There will never be an episode of mania/hypomania in this condition.

questions.text: Which type of mechanical asphyxia does the image shown below represent?
questions.solution:
The type of mechanical asphyxia shown in the image is mugging.

Mugging is a type of strangulation caused by holding the neck of the victim in the crook of the elbow. Pressure is then exerted either on the front of the larynx or at one or both sides by the forearm and upper arm. In mugging, the attack is usually made from behind. The image below shows strangulation by mugging.

Other options:

Option A: Burking is a type of homicidal asphyxial death comprising of smothering and traumatic asphyxia. In burking, the assaulter throws the victim to the ground and kneels or sits on the chest of the victim, preventing chest movements. He/she then covers the nose and mouth of the victim with his/her hands.

Option B: In bansdola, one strong bamboo or stick is placed across the back of the neck and another across the front. The victim is squeezed to death by tying both ends of the stick with rope. Sometimes, two sticks are used across the back and front of the upper part of the chest and squeezed forcibly. This causes laceration of the muscles, and rib fractures and interferes with respiration.

On examination, a bruise can be seen in the center of the neck across the windpipe, corresponding to the width of the stick or the substance used. A similar mark can be seen on the back of the neck if two sticks are used. 

Option D: Garrotting involves attacking the victim from behind using a ligature. The ligature is thrown around the unaware victim’s neck and then tightened by twisting it with a lever such as a rod or stick within the ligature. Earlier in Spain, garroting was an official method of judicial execution.

questions.text: A woman presented to the emergency department one hour after the spillage of hot coffee on her hands. On examination, the following finding was seen on her right hand. The injuries were extremely painful when touched. The capillary refilling time and pinprick sensations were normal. Which degree of burns would this fall under?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of a second-degree superficial burn. The points that favor the diagnosis are the presence of blisters, tenderness over the injured skin, normal capillary refilling time, and normal pinprick sensations. The epidermis and papillary dermis (the upper part of the dermis) are involved in this case. These burns will heal without scarring in 2 weeks.

According to the depth and the extent of tissue damage, burn injuries can be classified as follows:

  • First-degree burns: In this, there is damage to the epidermis. These injuries are extremely painful but do not blister. They have a normal capillary refilling time.
  • Second-degree burns (Partial-thickness burns): In this, there is damage to the epidermis and dermis. Depending on the extent of the dermal involvement, they can further be divided into superficial or deep.
    • Superficial: Involve the epidermis and upper part of the dermis (papillary). These injuries are red, moist, and extremely painful and blisters are present. The capillary return is clearly visible when the injured skin is blanched. Sensations are normal. They heal without scarring.
    • Deep: Involve the epidermis and the deeper dermis. These injuries are less painful and sensation is reduced. The capillaries do not blanch on pressure. They can lead to hypertrophic scarring.
  • Third-degree burns:  In this degree, there is damage to the epidermis, dermis, and subcutaneous tissue. The injuries have a hard leathery feel with the absence of sensation.
  • Fourth-degree burns: In this degree, there is damage to the underlying soft tissues as well.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presented with multiple erosions on the skin and oral mucosa. The histopathology of her skin biopsy is given below. Which of the following characteristic pattern is seen in the direct immunofluorescence study of such lesions?
questions.solution:
The given histological image shows the characteristic row of tombstones appearance seen in pemphigus vulgaris. The characteristic pattern seen in the direct immunofluorescence study of such lesions is the fish net pattern/ chicken-wire appearance. 

Pemphigus vulgaris is a chronic immunobullous disorder characterized by the presence of antibodies against desmosomal proteins expressed in the skin and mucosa. In the skin, desmoglein 1 is mostly seen in all layers, while desmoglein 3 is more in the lower layers. In the oral mucosa, desmoglein 3 is seen in all layers and desmoglein 1 is present in lower layers.

Clinically, the patients present with ill-defined, irregular, slow-to-heal oral lesions and erosions. Flaccid blisters filled with clear fluid may arise on normal skin or an erythematous base. The rupture of such blisters produces painful erosions and heals without scarring. Lesions may also involve the mucosa of the conjunctiva, nasopharynx, larynx, esophagus, urethra, vulva, or cervix. 

Nikolsky's sign is positive which is elicited by applying firm tangential sliding pressure with a finger on lesional or perilesional skin. This leads to the separation of the normal‐looking epidermis from the dermis, producing erosion.

Direct immunofluorescence is considered the most accurate confirmatory test of this condition. It shows intercellular IgG and C3 deposition on the surface of keratinocytes throughout the epidermis in normal, perilesional skin, in a characteristic fishnet/chickenwire appearance as seen below.

Histology shows a suprabasal split of the epidermis with a characteristic row of tombstone appearance as seen below.

Other investigations include a Tzanck smear showing acantholytic cells. Anti-Dsg ELISA assays can be used to monitor the disease activity.

Systemic corticosteroids are the mainstay of treatment for controlling the disease, improving the quality of life, and reducing disease activity.

Other options:

The speckled appearance of direct immunofluorescence is seen in systemic lupus erythematosus.

 

Focal granular deposits of IgA at the tips of dermal papillae are seen in dermatitis herpetiformis.

Linear IgG deposits at the dermo-epidermal junction in direct immunofluorescence are seen in bullous pemphigoid.

questions.text:
A young man with pulmonary tuberculosis presented with back pain. History revealed non-compliance to ATT, hence he was suspected to have Pott's spine. Pick the incorrect statement about the radiographic appearance of this condition.

ATT: Anti-tubercular treatment

choices.text: Bird's nest abscess signifies paravertebral abscess formation
Narrowing of the disc space is the earliest finding
Fibrous ankylosis of the spine is a common sequel
Sclerotic appearance indicates the healing stage

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement about Pott's spine is that fibrous ankylosis of the joints occurs as a sequel. Tuberculosis of all joints results in fibrous ankylosis except in the spine where bony ankylosis is a common sequel.

The tuberculous infection first involves the vertebral bodies and the intervertebral disc. Hence, the early radiographic features include the rarefaction/ osteopenic appearance of the involved vertebrae and the reduction or narrowing of the intervertebral disc space.

In later stages, the infection leads to para-vertebral abscess formation and vertebral destruction. These features can be seen on a radiograph as bird’s nest abscess and anterior wedging of vertebrae, respectively. When the disease is in the healing phase, the sclerotic appearance of vertebrae can be seen.

The below image shows the MRI spine of a patient with tuberculous spondylodiscitis of the lumbar spine. 

The below x-ray shows a soft tissue shadow suggestive of an abscess in the paravertebral region (bird nest abscess) presenting as the widened mediastinum.

Pott's spine occurs secondary to a pulmonary or gastrointestinal primary and spreads through the Batson's plexus of veins (paravertebral plexus). It most commonly involves the dorso-lumbar region. Image showing various parts and patterns of involvement in Pott's spine.

questions.text: An enthusiastic researcher found a positive correlation between the incidence of respiratory problems and the rising pollution in a district. He collected data from the district hospitals and the pollution control board. What is the type of study done here?
questions.solution:
The study described above is an example of an ecological study.

The ecological study is a type of analytical study that analyzes the health status and its relation with other variables. It is also called correlational study, and it uses population as a unit of study.

In the given scenario, the study was done with the district population, from which we can infer that the population was taken as the unit of the study. Also, the study was done to correlate the incidence of respiratory problems and pollution in the existing community.

Related Pearl: Types of Epidemiological Study Designs

Types of Epidemiological Study Designs

The flow chart below gives a glance into the types of epidemiological study designs and where they are generally used.

Note: Descripitve study is used to formulate aetiological hypothesis of a disease. Whereas analytical study is used to test the hypothesis (i.e to accept or reject the hypothesis).

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

In a case-control study, progression is from effect (disease) to cause (exposure) as the outcome or disease has already occurred. It is also called a retrospective study.

Design of case-control study:

 

  • Steps of case control study:
    • Selection of cases and controls
    • Matching
    • Measurement of exposure
    • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
  • Advantages of case control study:
    • Easy to carry out, rapid and inexpensive
    • Requires few subjects, no risk to subjects
    • Used to investigate rare diseases
    • Different etiological factors can be studied and risk factors can be identified
    • No attrition problems, minimal ethical problems
  • Disadvantages of case control study:
    • Relies on memory or past records giving rise to bias
    • Selection of appropriate control groups is difficult
    • Incidence cannot be measured
    • Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors
    • Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis
    • Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate

Related Pearl: Cohort Study

  • A cohort study progresses from cause (exposure) to effect (disease).
  • It is also known as forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study.
  • Design of a cohort study:
    • Types of cohort study:
      • Prospective (concurrent) cohort studies
      • Retrospective (historical) cohort studies
      • Combination cohort studies
    • Steps of cohort study:
      • Selection of study subjects
      • Obtaining data on exposure
      • Selection of comparison groups
      • Follow-up
      • Analysis in terms of incidence rates and estimation of risk
    • Advantages of cohort study:
      • Incidence can be calculated
      • Several possible outcomes related to exposure can be studied at the same time
      • Provides direct estimate of relative risk
      • Calculation of dose-response ratio
      • Minimization of certain biases
    • Disadvantages of cohort study:
      • Cannot use for uncommon diseases
      • Expensive, requires a large population and longer time
      • Many common administrative and ethical problems
      • High attrition and selection of subjects is difficult
      • Dynamism of diagnostics is difficult to incorporate
      • Tends to alter the behaviour of subjects known as Hawthorne effect.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man who developed severe tachycardia was rushed to the emergency room. The resident begins to massage the carotid region of his neck to bring down the heart rate. Which of the following mechanisms is responsible for this phenomenon?

choices.text: Increased activity of rostral ventrolateral medulla

questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the doctor has performed a carotid sinus massage to slow the heart rate. This stimulates the baroreceptor reflex leading to an increased afferent nerve/ glossopharyngeal nerve firing to the nucleus tractus solitarius. 

Carotid sinus massage

Procedure- It is performed with the patient supine and the head turned slightly away from the side being stimulated. Before performing massage the doctor should always auscultate to check for the presence of carotid bruit. If bruit is present, it should not be performed. The area of the carotid sinus, at the artery’s bifurcation, is palpated with two fingers at the angle of the jaw until a good pulse is felt. A minimal amount of pressure is applied over the carotid sinus. If there is no effect, a side-to-side or rotating motion of the fingers over the site is performed for up to 5 seconds. ECG should be performed to assess the response.

Mechanism

Pressure over the carotid sinus stimulates the baroreceptors. These signals are transmitted through small Hering’s nerves to the glossopharyngeal nerves and then to the nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS) in the medulla. These signals release glutamate and activate the CVLM (caudal ventrolateral medulla). This in turn inhibits RVLM (rostral ventrolateral medulla) considered the vasoconstrictor center for the brain and the heart. Simultaneously, this pathway also excites the vagal parasympathetic center. The stimulation of the vagus results in a slowing of impulse generation in the SA node and a slowing of conduction velocity in the AV node. This in total combination results in lowering of blood pressure and heart rate.

Related Pearl: Factors Affecting Heart Rate

Heart rate is accelerated by
  • Decreased activity of arterial baroreceptors
  • Increased activity of atrial stretch receptors
  • Inspiration
  • Excitement
  • Anger
  • Pain
  • Hypoxia
  • Exercise
  • Thyroid hormones
  • Fever

The Heart is slowed by
  • Increased activity of arterial baroreceptors
  • Expiration
  • Grief
  • Stimulation of pain fibers in trigeminal nerve
  • Increased intracranial pressure

questions.text: A 27-year-old primigravida woman at 34 weeks of gestation is reported to have an amniotic fluid index of 4 cm. Which of the following fetal anomaly can be associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
An amniotic fluid index(AFI) of 4 cm is suggestive of oligohydramnios which can be associated with renal agenesis.

Oligohydramnios is a condition where there is decreased production of amniotic fluid. Sonographically, it is defined when the single deepest pocket of liquor is <2 cm or when the amniotic fluid index (AFI) is less than 5 cm (less than 5 percentile).

The fetus begins producing urine between 8 - 11 weeks of gestation. However, it does not become a major part of the composition of amniotic fluid until the second trimester. For this reason, fetuses with kidney abnormalities do not become evident until after 18 weeks of gestation. 

Causes of Oligohydraminios:

  • Placental abnormalities: Amnion nodosum (failure of secretion by the cells of the amnion covering the placenta)
  • Maternal complications leading to uteroplacental insufficiency: pre-eclampsia, vascular disease
  • Renal Anomalies:
    • Bilateral renal agenesis
    • Bilateral multicystic dysplastic kidney
    • Unilateral renal agenesis with contralateral multicystic dysplastic kidney
    • The infantile form of autosomal recessive polycystic kidney dis­ease
    • Fetal bladder outlet obstruction - posterior urethral valves, urethral atresia, or stenosis
  • Complex fetal anomalies: persistent cloaca and sireno­melia (mermaid syndrome).
  • Post-dated pregnancy
  • Drugs: ACE inhibitors, ARBs, NSAIDs when taken in the 2nd or 3rd trimester

Consequently, polyhydramnios is defined as a deepest vertical pocket of more than 8 cm or an AFI of more than 24 cm. There are various mechanisms that can lead to polyhydramnios such as: 

  • Maternal causes
    • Diabetes(Overt diabetes/Gestational diabetes)
    • Cardiac diseases
    • Renal Diseases
  • Fetal causes
    • Neural tube defects
    • Anencephaly
    • Cleft lip/palate, micrognathia
    • Congenital diaphragmatic hernia
    • Esophageal and duodenal atresia
    • Aneuploidy
    • Hydrops fetalis due to Rh alloimmunization, nonimmune hydrops, cardiothoracic anomalies, fetal cirrhosis and fetal TORCH infections, parvovirus B19 infection
    • Twin pregnancy, Twin to Twin transfusion syndrome
    • Bartter syndrome
    • Sacrococcygeal teratoma
    • High-output cardiac states
  • Placental causes
    • Chorangioma of placenta

questions.text: A young woman presented with a butterfly-shaped malar rash, a history of recurrent oral ulcers, and pain in multiple joints. Investigations revealed pancytopenia and IgG antibodies to double-stranded DNA. What is her diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This woman with a butterfly-shaped malar rash, a history of recurrent oral ulcers, pain in multiple joints with thrombocytopenia, and antibodies to double-stranded DNA has a diagnosis of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

SLE is an autoimmune disorder that results in damage to multiple organs and organ systems in the body most commonly seen in women of reproductive age.  

Clinical and immunological manifestations in SLE:

  1. Skin
    • acute, subacute cutaneous manifestations (photosensitivity, malar or maculopapular rash)
    • chronic cutaneous manifestations (discoid lupus, panniculitis, lichen planus like) 
  2. Oral or nasal ulcers
  3. Non-scarring alopecia
  4. Synovitis involving ≥2 joints
  5. Serositis (pleurisy, pericarditis)
  6. Renal: 
    • Protein/Creatinine ratio >0.5
    • RBC casts
  7. Neurologic: seizures, psychosis, myelitis, neuropathy, confusional state
  8. Hemolytic anemia
  9. Leukopenia
  10. Thrombocytopenia
  11. Immunological manifestations
    • Antinuclear antibodies >reference value (positive in >98% patients)
    • Anti-dsDNA >reference value (specific)
    • Anti-Smith antibody (specific)
    • Antiphospholipid antibody (lupus anticoagulant, false-positive rapid plasma reagin)
    • Low serum complement

To diagnose SLE, at least 4 out of 11 of the above criteria must be positive. However, if a renal biopsy is suggestive of lupus nephritis and lupus autoantibodies are positive then four criteria are not required. 

Other options: 

Option A: Dermatomyositis is an inflammatory myopathy that presents with symmetrical weakness in the proximal muscles. Classical dermatological manifestations include- gottron's papules (raised erythematous rash) on the knuckles, elbows, shawl sign on the back, and the heliotrope rash over the eyelids (erythematous discoloration with periorbital edema). Laboratory findings include elevated creatinine kinase levels and autoantibodies like anti-Mi2.

Option B: Behcet's disease is a multisystem disorder that requires recurrent oral ulceration plus two of the following criteria for a definitive diagnosis -

  • Recurrent genital ulceration
  • Occular lesions
  • Skin lesions 
  • Positive pathergy test

Laboratory findings are usually non-specific signs of inflammation and elevated C-reactive protein levels.

Option C: Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic inflammatory disease that results in damage to the articular cartilages. It can also have a broad range of extra-articular manifestations. The autoantibodies seen in this disease are anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibodies and rheumatoid factor.
